{
"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient has been diagnosed with HIV and syphilis. The RPR test is positive with a titer of 1:64, which suggests that the patient has secondary or latent syphilis. The FTA-ABS test is also positive, confirming the diagnosis of syphilis. Since the patient's neurological examination is normal and he has no symptoms, it is likely that the patient has asymptomatic syphilis.

The presence of HIV infection does not change the management of syphilis in this patient. In patients with HIV, syphilis can present differently than in immunocompetent individuals. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommend treating syphilis according to the stage of disease, regardless of HIV status.

In this case, since the patient has asymptomatic syphilis, treatment should be initiated. The CDC recommends a single injection of benzathine penicillin G as the recommended treatment for asymptomatic syphilis in patients with HIV infection.",
"answer_choice": "D"
